paragraph: CHAPTER 53.
As soon as they had carried up the whole of the cargo, they secured the boat, and went up to the house to sleep.  Just as they went in, Remus came bounding up to them with a letter round his neck.
tokens: carry whole cargo secure boat go house sleep go come bound letter neck

paragraph: "Here's the dog, William," said Ready; "he won't go home after all."
tokens: dog say ready go

paragraph: "How provoking!  I made sure he would go back; I really am disappointed. We will give him nothing to eat, and then he will; but, dear me, Ready! this is not the paper I tied round his neck.  I think not.  Let me see." William took the paper, opened it, and read--
tokens: provoking make sure go disappointed give eat ready paper tie neck think let see take paper open read

paragraph: "Dear William:--Your letter arrived safe, and we are glad you are well. Write every day, and God bless you; it was very clever of you and Remus. Your affectionate mother, SELINA SEAGRAVE."
tokens: dear letter arrive safe glad well write day bless clever affectionate mother

paragraph: "Well, it is clever," said Ready; "I'm sure I had no idea he had gone; and his coming back again, too, when he was ordered."
tokens: clever say ready sure have idea go come order

paragraph: "Dear Remus, good dog," said William, caressing it: "now I'll give you a good supper, for you deserve it."
tokens: dear good dog say caress give good supper deserve

paragraph: "So he does, sir.  Well, you've established a post on the island, which is a great improvement.  Seriously, William, it may prove very useful."
tokens: sir establish post island great improvement prove useful

paragraph: "At all events it will be a great comfort to my mother."
tokens: event great comfort mother

paragraph: "Yes, especially as we shall be obliged all three to be here when we fit up the storehouse, and make the proposed alterations.  Now I think we had better go to bed, for we must be up with the lark to-morrow."
tokens: oblige fit storehouse make propose alteration think have good go bed lark

paragraph: "Here I suppose we ought to say, up with the parrots; for they are the only land birds on the island."
tokens: suppose say parrot only land bird island

paragraph: "You forget the pigeons; I saw one of them in the wood the other day. Good night!"
tokens: forget pigeon see wood other day good night

paragraph: The next morning, they were off before breakfast.  The boat was soon loaded, and they returned under sail.  They then breakfasted, and having left the things they had brought on the beach, that they might lose no time, they set off again, and returned with another cargo two hours before dusk; this they landed, and then secured the boat.  As soon as they were in the house, William wrote on a piece of paper:--
tokens: next morning breakfast boat load return sail breakfast leave thing bring beach lose time set return cargo hour dusk land secure boat house write piece paper

paragraph: "Dear Mamma:--We have brought round two cargoes to-day.  All well, and very tired.  Yours, WILLIAM."
tokens: dear bring round cargoe day tired

paragraph: Remus did not require any teaching this time.  William patted him, and said, "Good dog.  Now, Remus, go back--go home, sir;" and the dog wagged his tail, and set off immediately.
tokens: require teaching time patt say good dog go go sir dog wagg tail set

paragraph: Before they were in bed, the dog returned with the answer.
tokens: bed dog return answer

paragraph: "How fast he must run, Ready! he has not been away more than two hours."
tokens: run ready more hour

paragraph: "No.  So, now, Remus, you shall have plenty of supper, and plenty of patting and coaxing, for you are a clever, good little dog."
tokens: have plenty supper plenty patting coaxing clever good little dog

paragraph: The next day, as they had to take the two cargoes up to the house, they could only make one trip to the cove.  On Saturday they only made one trip, as they had to return to the tents, which they did by water, having first put a turtle into the boat; on their arrival, they found them all at the little harbour, waiting to receive them.
tokens: next day have take cargoe house make trip cove make trip have return tent do water put turtle boat arrival find little harbour wait receive

paragraph: "Well, William, you did keep your promise and send me a letter by post," said Mrs Seagrave.  "How very delightful it is!  I shall have no fear now when you are all away."
tokens: keep promise send letter post say delightful have fear

paragraph: "I must teach Romulus and Vixen to do the same, mamma."
tokens: teach do same mamma

paragraph: "And I'll teach the puppies," said Tommy.
tokens: teach puppy say

paragraph: "Yes, Tommy; by the time you can write a letter, the puppies will be old enough to carry it," said Ready.  "Come, Albert, I'll carry you up; you and I haven't had a game of play for a long while.  How does the ditch and hedge get on, Mr Seagrave?"
tokens: time write letter puppy old carry say ready come carry have game play long while ditch hedge get

paragraph: "Pretty well, Ready," replied Mr Seagrave; "I have nearly finished two sides.  I think by the end of next week I shall have pretty well inclosed it."
tokens: ready reply finish side think end next week inclose

paragraph: "Well, sir, you must not work too hard, there is no great hurry; William and I can get through a great deal together."
tokens: sir work be great hurry get great deal

paragraph: "It is my duty to work, Ready; and I may add, it is a pleasure."
tokens: duty work ready add pleasure

paragraph: As they were at supper the conversation turned upon the cleverness shown by the dog Remus.
tokens: supper conversation turn cleverness show dog

paragraph: Mr Seagrave narrated many instances of the sagacity of animals, when William asked the question of his father: "What is the difference then between reason and instinct?"
tokens: narrate many instance sagacity animal ask question father difference reason instinct

paragraph: "The difference is very great, William, as I will explain to you; but I must first observe, that it has been the custom to say that man is governed by reason, and animals by instinct, alone.  This is an error. Man has instinct as well as reason; and animals, although chiefly governed by instinct, have reasoning powers."
tokens: difference great explain observe custom say man govern reason animal instinct alone error man have instinct reason animal govern instinct have reasoning power

paragraph: "In what points does man show that he is led by instinct?"
tokens: point man show lead instinct

paragraph: "When a child is first born, William, it acts by instinct only: the reasoning powers are not yet developed; as we grow up, our reason becomes every day more matured, and gains the mastery over our instinct, which decreases in proportion."
tokens: child bear act instinct reasoning power develop grow reason become day mature gain mastery instinct decrease proportion

paragraph: "Then when we have grown to a good old age, I suppose we have no instinct left in us?"
tokens: grow good old age suppose have instinct leave

paragraph: "Not so, my dear boy; there is one and a most powerful instinct implanted in man which never deserts him on this side of the grave.  It is the fear, not of death, but of utter annihilation, that of becoming nothing after death.  This instinctive feeling could not have been so deeply implanted in us, but as an assurance that we shall not be annihilated after death, but that our souls shall still exist, although our bodies shall have perished.  It may be termed the instinctive evidence of a future existence."
tokens: dear boy be powerful instinct implant man desert side grave fear death utter annihilation become death instinctive feeling implant assurance annihilate death soul exist body perish term instinctive evidence future existence

paragraph: "That is very true, Mr Seagrave," observed Ready.
tokens: true observe ready

paragraph: "Instinct in animals, William," continued Mr Seagrave, "is a feeling which compels them to perform certain acts without previous thought or reflection; this instinct is in full force at the moment of their birth; it was therefore perfect in the beginning, and has never varied.  The swallow built her nest, the spider its web, the bee formed its comb, precisely in the same way four thousand years ago, as they do now.  I may here observe, that one of the greatest wonders of instinct is the mathematical form of the honeycomb of the bee, which has been proved by demonstration to be that by which is given the greatest possible saving of time and labour."
tokens: instinct animal continue feeling compel perform certain act previous thought reflection instinct full force moment birth perfect beginning vary swallow build nest spider web bee form comb same way year do observe great wonder instinct mathematical form honeycomb bee prove demonstration give great possible save time labour

paragraph: "But that is all pure instinct, papa; now you said that animals had reasoning powers.  Will you point out to me how they show that they have?"
tokens: pure instinct papa say animal have reasoning power point show have

paragraph: "I will, my dear boy; but we had better defer it till another evening. It is now time to go to bed."
tokens: dear boy defer evening time go bed
